Obedience to my Father!—And ſhall I have the honour of conducting your Ladyſhip to the Company?—A pretty Lover-like requeſt truly!—But this coldneſs to me proceeds from a cauſe I now underſtand—This morning, what fire was there in his eyes! what animation in his countenance! whenever he addreſs'd himſelf to that creature Mr. Drummond brought here?—Would his requeſt to her have been to conduct her to Company?—No, no;—But I muſt be cautious—I muſt be patient now—but you will find, Sir, when I poſſeſs the privileges of a Wife, I ſhall not ſo eaſily give them up—your fiery glances, if not directed to me, ſhall at leaſt, in my preſence, be addreſſed to no other.

lg.l: Haſte, • aſte, ye fiery Steeds of Day,
In Ocean's boſom hide your beams!
Mild Evening, in her penſive gray
More ſ • ft, and more alluring ſeems.
Yet why invoke the penſive Eve,
Or, ſighing, chide refulg • nt Morn?
Their ſhifting moments can't relieve
The heart by pangs of abſ • nce torn.

sp.p:
Hang Muſic—it only makes me melancholy—Heigh-ho '—theſe Lovers inſect me too, I believe—Seducive Italy! what are your attractions? Oh, for Fortunatus's cap—I'd convince myſelf in a moment if my doubts are
juſtly founded—And ſuppoſe they ſhould—what then?—Ah! they think I am made of ice, whilſt the gaiety of my diſpoſition only ſerves to conceal a heart as tenderly ſuſceptible as the moſt ſerious of my ſex can poſſeſs—
Ah, my dear Ma'am, I am rejoiced to ſee you; I have been juſt long enough alone to be tired of myſelf, and to be charmed at ſo agreeable a relief.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Can that ever be the caſe with Miſs Sidney? I thought you had poſſeſs'd the happieſt flow of ſpirits in the world.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pho!—your great ſpirits are mere Jack-a-lanterns in the brain—they dance about, ſhine, and make vagaries—while thoſe who poſſeſs happineſs, ſoberly and quietly enjoy their treaſure.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Indeed! I hope dulneſs is not your criterion of happineſs—if it is, there are few aſſemblies where you'll not find a great number to envy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, no—Dulneſs is the character of thoſe who are too wiſe, not too happy.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Two Ladies in council—on faſhion, or news?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: On a better ſubject—laughing at the ſlaves we have made, and forging chains for more.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That's not the buſineſs of fine Women—Nature meant to ſave them the trouble of plotting—for traps and chains, ſhe beſtowed ſparkling eyes, and timid bluſhes, with a whole multitude of graces, that hang about the form, and wanton in the air.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, after all, Men are delightful creatures—flattery, cards, and ſcandal, help one thro' the day tolerably well—I don't know how we ſhould exiſt without 'em in the country.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And which of 'em would you relinquiſh in town?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not flattery, becauſe it keeps one in ſpirits, and gives a glow to the complexion—Scandal, you may take away—but pray leave us cards, to keep us awake, with the faſhionable world, on Sunday evenings.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And, in lieu of ſcandal, you'll be content with conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ridiculous! Conqueſt is not ſuch an object with Women, as the Men imagine—for my part, I ſhould conceive a net that would catch the hearts of the whole ſex, a property of very little value.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: But, you would think it a very pleaſant one, my gentle Cuz. or, at leaſt [archly] you'd pick out one happy favourite before you gave the reſt to deſpair.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Poſitively no—I don't know one that I ſhould not let fly away with the reſt.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Now, how can you fib, with ſuch an unbluſhing face? This debate, Madam, [to Emily] will let you into Bella's ſecret—ſhe has, at this moment, an image in her heart, that gives a flat contradiction to her tongue.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Indeed!—you make your aſſertion with great effrontery—but now, to compliment your diſcernment, whoſe image do you think of?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ha, Bella—liſten with your greedieſt ears to catch the tranſporting ſound—breathe not, ye ſofteſt Zephyrs! be ſilent, ye harmonious Spheres! while I articulate the name of—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [ſtopping her ears] Oh, I won't hear it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Belville!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, frightful!—don't attend to him—George's belief is always under the influence of his fancy.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: In this inſtance, if I may judge from your looks, he has not hinted at a fiction.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Indeed you are miſtaken; his gueſs might have been as good, if you had named Preſter John.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hum—I wiſh it may be ſo, for I have heard a ſtory about a certain Lady on the Continent, whom a certain Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thinks handſomer than Bella Sydney—mortifying—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay more, to whom be devotes his hours.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: His heart

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: On whom he doats.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pſha!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Grows melancholy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay, fights for her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Lives only at her feet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You are really very inſupportable, Sir—do find ſome other ſubject to amuſe yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! the Gudgeon has bit—See, Madam, a Coquette ſtruggling with the conſciouſneſs of love,—are not thoſe pouts, and angry bluſhes, proofs of Belville's happineſs?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I cannot perceive theſe proofs—Mr. Belville, perhaps, is not in ſo enviable a ſtate.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, you are a good Girl, and, I aſſure you, perfectly right—Lovers, thank our ſtars! are too plenty, for an abſent one to give us much pain.—What, turn your arms on your aſſociate, George!—I'll break the league, and diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You dare not, you love miſchief too well—it is as dear to you as the ſighs of your Lover.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A-propos! where's Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: In the garden probably—ſighing to the winds—and I wiſh you'd find him—and leave us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! Perhaps they'll waft his ſighs to Harriet—and ſhe muſt not hear 'em yet—and ſo, Sir Charles—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, pray make me one of your party.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Stay, Madam, I entreat you—believe me, they will not thank you—I'll tell you the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I'll hear it from Miſs Sydney.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay, if you are determined—

In vain do I endeavour to conceal it from myſelf—This ſpot has charms for me, that I can find in no other—here have I ſeen—perhaps for the laſt time, Sir Charles Seymour. My Couſin's preſence was unlucky—I ſhould have heard him—but it would have been a crime in him to have talked to me of love—an inſult that I muſt have reſented—and yet 'tis the only ſubject on which I could wiſh to have heard him. Bleſs me! he's here again—he haunts this place—but he does not obſerve me, and I'll conceal myſelf; for I feel I could not now behave with proper reſerve.

Ha, not here then!—Sweet reſemblance of her I love! come from thy hiding-place. [takes a picture from his boſom, and kiſſes it.] In her abſence thou art the deareſt object to my eyes. What a face is this!
sp.l: "'Tis beauty truly bleſt, whoſe red and white
"Nature's own ſweet and cunning hand laid on."

div.stage: Enter GEORGE. Catches his hand with the picture.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ho ho!—ſo the Picture's come home from the Painter's, is it, Sir—and the drapery quite to your mind?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: The artifice I uſed to obtain it, thoſe who love can pardon.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And how many times a day doſt thou break the decalogue in worſhipping that Image?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Every hour that I live. I gaze on it till I think it looks, and ſpeaks to me; it lies all night on my heart, and is the firſt object I addreſs in the morning.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh, complete your character, and turn Monk—'tis plain you're half a Papiſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Why condemn me to cells and penitence?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That you mayn't violate the laws of Nature, by pretending to a character for which ſhe never deſigned you. Your bonds, inſtead of ſilken fetters, appear to be hempen cords. Come, confeſs, have not you been examining on which of theſe trees you would be moſt gracefully pendent?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: That gaieté de coeur, George, bears no mark of the tender paſſion; and, to be plain, I believe you know very little about it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You are confoundedly miſtaken—we are both Lovers, but the difference between us lies thus: Cupid to me is a little familiar rogue, with an arch leer—and cheeks dimpled with continual ſmiles—To you—an aweful Deity, deck'd out in his whole regalia of darts, flames, and quivers, and ſo forth—I play with him—you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Spare yourſelf the trouble of ſo long an explanation—All you would ſay is, that you love with hope—I with deſpair.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Very conciſe, and moſt pathetically expreſt—melancholy ſuits your features, Charles—'twere pity your Miſtreſs ſhould encourage you; it would deprive you of that ſomething in your air which is ſo touching—Ha! ha! ha!—poor Seymour! Come, let us go in ſearch of the girls, they are gone to the wood; who knows but you may find a nymph there, who'll have the kindneſs to put hanging and drowning out of your head?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.l: Oh, would ſweet Celia meet me there,
With ſoften'd looks, and gentler air,
Tranſported, to the Wood I'd fly,
The happieſt Swain beneath the ſky;
Sighs and complaints I'd give the wind,
And IO's ſing, were Celia kind.

div.stage: [As he repeats the verſes, George, laughing, ſcans them on his fingers.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Cupid is deaf, as well as blind.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Her picture in his boſom, and kiſs it with ſuch rapture too! Well—I am glad I am convinced—I am perfectly at eaſe. He loves them without hope, and George was miſtaken in ſuppoſing him ſo near marriage—but he loves notwithſtanding—her picture lies all night on his heart, and her idea is never abſent from his mind—Well, be it ſo—I am perfectly at eaſe, and ſhall no longer find a difficulty in aſſuming an indifference that is become real—Oh, Seymour!

Inſolent wretch!—Nothing leſs than the conviction of my own ſenſes could have induced me to believe ſo ſhocking an indecorum—I ſaw her myſelf look at him with eyes that were downright gloting—I ſaw him ſnatch her hand, and preſs it to his lips, with an ardour that is inconceivable—and when the creature pretended to bluſh, and made a reluctant effort to withdraw it—my Youth, ſo full of veneration and reſpect for me, refuſed to reſign it—till the creature had given him a gracious ſmile of reconciliation—Heavens! they are coming this way—ſure they do not perceive me—See there!—Nay, if you will come here.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I entreat you, Sir, not to perſiſt in following me—You'll force me to appeal to Mr. Drummond for protection.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You need no protection, Madam, that you will not find in my reſpect—But you are barbarous to deprive me of converſing with you—'tis a felicity, I have ſo lately taſted, that 'tis no wonder I am greedy of it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: If you believe your attentions would not diſpleaſe me in my proper character—I ought to be offended that you addreſs them to a perſon, of whoſe name and family you are ignorant.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Can a name deprive you of that face, that air—or rob you of your mind—of what then am I ignorant?—'tis thoſe I addreſs with the moſt paſſionate vows of—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
I poſitively will not liſten to you—However, if the acquaintance ſhould place us on a footing, I'll then
converſe with you—if on my own terms. [Lady D. liſtening—Aye, or on any terms.] I have no diſlike to the charming freedom of the Engliſh manners—you ſhall be as gallant as you pleaſe; but I give you notice, the inſtant you become dangerous, I ſhall be grave.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How dangerous—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Oh, the moment you grow of conſequence enough to endanger my heart, I ſhall ſhut myſelf from you—but as long as you continue harmleſs, you may play.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This is not to be borne—I will not be harmleſs—I declare open war againſt your heart, not in play, but downright earneſt.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Nay, then, I muſt collect my forces to oppoſe you—my heart will ſtand a long ſiege, depend on it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: If you'll promiſe it ſhall yield at laſt, a ten years ſiege will be richly rewarded.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Oh, no; I make no promiſes—try your forces; if you ſhould poſſeſs yourſelf of it in ſpite of me—I can only bewail its captivity.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your permiſſion to take the field is all I can at preſent hope; and thus on my knees, dear charming Creature—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: There's veneration and reſpect!

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Hold, Sir—I will be ſo generous to tell you, that whenever you kneel I ſhall fly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And I'll purſue—till my Atalanta confeſſes I have won the prize.

div.stage: [As Geo. is following Emily, Lady D. comes out againſt him with an angry reproachful air, and paſſes him.]

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: So,—there's a look! what a bleſſed Motherin-law I ſhall have!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What!—not ſtay even to explain—to apologiſe—follow her before my face—oh, Monſters, Furies! yes, yes, ſhe'll yield without the trouble of a ten years ſiege—ſhe can ſcarcely hold out ten minutes—oh, ye ſhall both ſuffer for this—I will go this inſtant—I will do ſomething.

sp.speaker: S • ſ • n.
sp.p:
Hah, my good Lady, is it ſo? ha, ha, ha! I muſt ſee if I can't make myſelf uſeful here. A Lady, who like my miſtreſs gives way to her moſt unbridled paſſions, is the only one worth being ſerved by a girl of ſpirit and intrigue. I'll follow, and aid your Ladyſhip with my counſel before you
have time to cool— [going, returns.]—So—'tis needleſs, here ſhe ebbs, like a ſtormy ſea.

div.stage: Enter Lady DINAH, not ſeeing SUSAN.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: A moment's reflection has convinced me I ſhould be wrong—he muſt not ſuſpect that I influence his Father againſt the minion—nor will I allow her the ſatisfaction of thinking ſhe gives to me the pangs of jealouſy—but I will not loſe him—ſomething muſt be done.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady, I was witneſs to the whole affair—Oh, a baſe man! I could have trampled him under my feet.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Baſe, indeed! but 'tis on her my reſentment chiefly falls—oh, Suſan—revenge!

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: I am ſure my heart achs for you, my Lady—there's nothing I would not do—Oh, ſhe's an artful ſlut.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: She's as dangerous as artful—I muſt be rid of her, yet I know not how.—Oh France! for thy Baſtile, for thy Lettres de Cachet!

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: There are ways and means here, my Lady—Miſs told a fine tale to get into the houſe, and I fancy I can tell as fine a tale to get her out of it, and I ſhou'd think it neither ſin nor ſhame in the ſervice of ſo good a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: If thou canſt contrive any method—I care not what—any plan to rid me of her; command my fortune.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, dear my Lady, as to that—as to your fortune, my Lady, that's out of the queſtion—but I know your Ladyſhip's generoſity—I think I could ſend her packing,—perhaps before night.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Can you!—The inſtant ſhe goes, I'll give you two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: She ſhall go, my Lady, if I have invention, or Jarvis a tongue.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Jarvis! Are you mad?—I wou'd not have him ſuſpect that I am concerned in the affair, for the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, dear my Lady—I vow I wou'd not mention your name to him—no, not for another two hundred pounds;—no, no, Miſs ſhall be got rid of, without giving Jarvis, or any one, the leaſt reaſon to ſuſpect that your Ladyſhip is privy to the matter.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I am convinced ſhe is an impoſtor, and I wonder Mr. Hargrave doesn't ſee it—but there will be more labour in rouſing his ſtupid apprehenſion, than in explaining to an enthuſiaſt the conceptions of a Bolingbroke.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: I am more afraid of Mr. Drummond than him.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Aye—he will ſupport that Girl's intereſt, in order to mortify me—

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: That doesn't ſignify, my Lady—I have a card as good as any he holds to play againſt him—your Ladyſhip muſt have ſeen that the old Juſtice has full as much weight with the 'Squire, as Mr. Drummond.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I obſerve that Mr. Hargrave is continually wavering between them—they influence his actions like two principal ſenſes—Mr. Drummond is the friend of his underſtanding, the other of his humour.—But what is the card you mean to play?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: I mean to play one of his ſenſes againſt the other, my Lady, that's all—for I am miſtaken if I can't govern the Juſtice, as much as his whole five put together.

sp.speaker: Lady. D.
sp.p: That is indeed a card—my hopes catch life at it—Suſan, ſay to him what you will, promiſe what you will—I ſuppoſe you have the way to the old fool's heart, and know by what road to reach it—at all events the Girl muſt be got rid of; the method I leave to you.—There's the dinner bell—I muſt walk a little to recover my compoſure, and then, I ſuppoſe, I may have the honour of ſitting for the young Lady's foil.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: I am ſure ſhe can't have a better—ha, ha, ha!—Two hundred pounds! Oh the charms of jealouſy and revenge—I might have ſerved one of your good ſort of orderly old women, 'till I had been grey—theſe two hundreds will quicken Mr. Jarvis a little—we ſhall ſee him more attentive, I fancy, than he has been, and then farewell to ſervitude—Hah, Jarvis!

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.l: "So look'd the Goddeſs of the Paphian Iſle,
"When Mars ſhe ſaw, and conquer'd with that ſmile."
sp.p: My dear Goddeſs, I kiſs your fingers—I have been hunting for you in every walk in the garden.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Why—what did you want with me, Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why, faith, I have the ſame kind of neceſſity for you, that a Beau has for a looking-glaſs—you admire me, and keep me in good humour with myſelf.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, if you want to be put in temper, I've got an excellent cordial. Now for your parts—now to prove yourſelf the clever fellow that you think you are.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: That you think, my dear, you mean—but what ex-

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Liſten!—We have diſcovered that the young 'Squire thinks eighteen a prettier age than fifty—that he prefers natural roſes to Warren's, and that gravity and wiſdom are no match for the fire of two hazel eyes, aſſiſted by the reaſoning of ſmiles and dimples.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: And he's in the right on't—didn't I tell you this morning they reckon'd without their hoſt?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Here has he been on his knees at the feet of the Damſel, and her Ladyſhip behind that buſh, amuſing herſelf with his tranſports—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—I warrant her, 'tis the only tranſports ſhe'll ever ſee him in. George Hargrave marry our old Lady! no, no—I have a very good opinion of that young fellow; he's exactly what I ſhould be, if I was heir to his Father's acres—juſt ſuch a ſpirited, careleſs deportment—a certain prevailing aſſurance—upon my ſoul, Suſan, you and I ought to have moved in a higher ſphere.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Come, come, you muſt conſider this affair in another light; 'twou'd be a ſhame, that becauſe this Girl has a pretty face, and was found weeping by a compaſſionate old Gentleman—it wou'd be a ſhame, I ſay, that for theſe reaſons, ſhe ſhou'd marry into a great Family, and cheat the Siſter of a Peer, of a Huſband—Read the ſtory this way, act with ſpirit, and our Lady will, on the day of our marriage, give us two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Humph!—on the day of our marriage—cannot you, Child, prevail on your Lady to give me the two hundred, without tacking that condition to it?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Pho, Sauce-box!—Well, but theſe two hundreds now—what will you do for 'em?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Do for 'em—Oh, any thing—the moſt extravagant thing in the world—run off with the girl—blow up the houſe—turn Turk—or marry you.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Well, but the buſineſs, Child, the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: The buſineſs is, that we muſt contrive to open ſome door for this Girl to walk out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: But how—upon what ground—when, and where?

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Why, if we could contrive the buſineſs, I have no doubt of the ſpirit and fire of your execution.—Do you remember the occupation which once gave employment to theſe talents of yours—I mean that of an itinerant Player?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p:
Oh, yes—I remember the barns that I have made
echo with the ravings of Oreſtes, and the ſtables in which I have ſighed forth the woes of Romeo.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Well, but have you any recollection of a pretty Juliet—a tall elegant Girl—in ſhort, do you not remember one of the ſtrolling party exceedingly like the ſtrange gueſt now in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Hum!—Why, what devil ſent thee to tempt me this morning?—ſo I am to ſell my honour—my honeſty—

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Pho, pho—honeſty and honour are ſentiments for people whoſe fortunes are made—let us once be independent, and we'll be as honourable and as honeſt as the beſt of 'em—ſo let's go in, and ſettle our plan.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Well—'tis the fate of great men to be in the hands of Women; and therefore, my ſweet Abigail—I am yours.

sp.speaker: BELLA.
sp.p: NAY, but hear him—hear him, Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Can this be you, Bella, who this morning ſeem'd fearful that I ſhould not treat him with ſufficient ſcorn—now perſuading me to allow a private interview to a Man who is profeſſedly the lover of another?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How apprehenſive you very delicate Ladies are! Why muſt you ſuppoſe he wants to talk to you about love—or on any topic, that his approaching marriage would make improper?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why—what can he have to ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Admit him, and he'll tell you—perhaps he wants to conſult your taſte about the trimmings of his wedding clothes—or to beg your choice in his ruffles—or—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pho!—this is downright ridicule.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Well then—you won't admit him? [ſeeming to go] I ſhall tell him you don't chooſe to ſee him, tho' he is going to
leave us directly—but I approve your caution, Harriet, you are perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Going to leave us directly, Bella!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Immediately, my dear—I heard him order his chaiſe, and mutter ſomething about inſupportable—but I think you'll be exceedingly imprudent in receiving his viſit, and adviſe you by all means to refuſe it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear Bella!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well then you will ſee him—I ſhall acquaint him with the ſucceſs of my embaſſy—but remember ſcorn, Harriet, ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Now, what am I to expect? my heart beats ſtrangely—but remember, fooliſh Girl, the picture of his Miſtreſs is in his boſom.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: The requeſt I ventured to make by Miſs Sidney, Madam, muſt appear ſtrange to you—the engagements which I—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Renders it an extraordinary requeſt indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I fear'd you would think ſo, and conſcious of thoſe engagements, I ſhou'd not have preſum'd to have made it—but as it's probably the laſt time I may ever ſee you—I ſeize it, to tell you that—I adore you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir Charles! I am aſtoniſhed,—in my Father's houſe at leaſt, I ſhould have been ſecure from ſuch an inſult.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Forgive me, I intreat you. Nothing could have forced this declaration from me, but my deſpair.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The engagement you talk of, Sir, ought to have prevented theſe effects of your deſpair.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I acknowledge it—and they have kept me ſilent ever ſince I arrived—but when I thought of leaving you in a few moments, I ſound the idea inſupportable.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The picture you wear, Sir Charles—might conſole you ſurely.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Hah—I thought you were ignorant, Madam, of my poſſeſſing it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Without doubt you did, Sir Charles—but no, Sir—I am acquainted with your wearing that Picture—and wonder how you could preſume—but I deſerve the inſult, for liſtening to you a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Oh, ſtay, Miſs Hargrave, I intreat you,—I will give up the picture, ſince it ſo offends you—yet how can I part from it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh, keep it, Sir—keep it by all means—you miſtake me entirely, Sir; I have no right to claim ſuch a ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: You have a right, Madam—here it is— [kiſſing and offering it] but do not rob me of it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Rob you of it!—in ſhort, Sir Charles, you redouble your rudeneſs every moment—

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: I did not think you would have ſo reſented it—but I reſign it to you, Madam—nay, you muſt take it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I take it, Sir! [Glances her eye on it, then takes it with an air of doubt]—My Picture!—aſtoniſhing!

div.stage: Enter GEORGE and BELLA, both laughing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Your picture, Madam!!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Look at the ſimpletons—na, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What a fine attitude!—do it again, Sir Charles—ha, ha, ha!—Well, Harriet—how do you like Sir Charles's Miſtreſs? Is ſhe as handſome as George repreſented her?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hold, hold! 'tis time now to have mercy. My dear Harriet, allow me to preſent to you my moſt valued friend, as the Man whom I ſhou'd rejoice to ſee your Huſband. To you, my Seymour, I preſent a Siſter, whoſe heart has no engagements that I am acquainted with, to ſuperſede your claim.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: I am ſpeechleſs with joy, and with amazement.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Forgive the embarraſment I have occaſion'd you—you have ſuffer'd ſomething; but your felicity will be heighten'd from the compariſon. My dear Harriet, Seymour has always loved you—the picture which ſo offended you is a proof, you cannot doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: And that you were ſo offended, is ſupreme felicity—ſtupid wretch—not to perceive my bliſs!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You have taken a liberty with me that I cannot pardon.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay, but you ſhall pardon it—and as a proof, give him back your picture this minute.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Return it to me, Madam, I intreat you [kneeling] I will receive it as the moſt precious gift.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come, give the poor thing its bauble.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well, take it, Sir—ſince you had no ſhare in this brilliant contrivance.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Eternal bleſſings on that hand!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You, George, are never ſo happy, as in exerciſing your wit, at my expence.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And you, Harriet, never ſo heartily forgave me in your Life, and therefore—

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Hold, George—I cannot bear Miſs Hargrave's ſuffering in this manner; I will take on myſelf the tranſporting office of defending her—this hour, Madam, I ſhall for ever remember with gratitude, and will endeavour to deſerve it, by a life devoted to your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come, Harriet—I muſt take you away, that Sir Charles may bring down his raptures to the ſtandard of common mortals—at preſent, I ſee his in the clouds.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'Tis merciful to relieve me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Charming Miſs Sydney—I'll never quarrel with your vivacity again.—But why have I been made to ſuffer thus?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Becauſe you did not tell me why you wanted my Siſter's picture—but I have taken a friendly vengeance; my plot has told you more of my Siſter's heart in a few hours, than all your ſighs and humility, wou'd have obtained in as many months.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: For which I thank you—and my preſent happineſs receives a brighter glow from this illuſion of miſery—I'll fly and pour out my joy and gratitude, at the feet of my charming Harriet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, ſtay, ſtay—we may want your aſſiſtance. Here's your Father coming, George. Your repartee to Lady Dinah at dinner, ſpoilt her digeſtion—and ſhe's been repreſenting you—that's all.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I hope ſhe repreſented her ſneer too, which ſuffuſed with tears the lovelieſt eyes in the world. Could I do leſs than ſupport h • r againſt the ill-humour of that antiquated pedant?—By Jupiter, I'll draw her in colours to my Father, that ſhall make him ſhrink from the fate he is preparing for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why, George, how's this?—Dy'e know what you've done?—you've affronted Lady Dinah.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I did not deſign to affront her, Sir—I only meant to convince her that ſhe ſhou'd not inſult the amiable young Lady, whom Mr. Drummond placed under your protection.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Don't tell me—amiable young Lady! How do you know what ſhe is?—on the footing you are with Lady Dinah, let me tell you, if ſhe had inſulted an hundred young Ladies, you ought not to have ſeen it—at leaſt, not reſented it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir—I did not conceive that Lady Dinah ſhou'd have aſſumed in your houſe—at leaſt till ſhe becomes your Wife—a right to—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What's that you ſay, Sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, to confeſs the truth, I am aſtoniſh'd at your partiality for that Lady—ſhe is the laſt woman in the world, whom I could wiſh to ſee in the place of my amiable Mother.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Your Mother!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I ſhou'd think it a breach of my duty, to ſee you plunge yourſelf into ſo irretrievable a fate, without acquainting you with my ſentiments—if you ſaw her in the light I do, Sir—you would think on your wedding day with horror.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why—why—are you mad?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: If you wiſhed to keep your engagements a ſecret, Sir—I am ſorry I mention'd the affair, but—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh—'tis no ſecret, Sir, I aſſure you—every body talks of it—for my part, I ſhall be quite happy in paying my reſpects to my new Aunt—I have put a coral ſtring in my tambour already, that I may finiſh it time enough for her firſt Boy to wear at its chriſtening.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir—I perceive that you have all that backwardneſs in obeying me that I expected, and, in order to conceal it, are attempting to throw the affair into ridicule—but I tell you it will not do—I know what I am about, and my commands ſhall not be diſputed.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Commands, Sir!—I am quite at a loſs—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Well then, to prevent further miſtakes, I acquaint you, that I deſign Lady Dinah for your Wife, and not your Mother—and moreover, that the marriage ſhall take place in a very few days. [going.]—And, d'ye hear?—acquaint your pert Couſin, that the coral ſtring will do for your firſt Boy.

div.stage: [A long pauſe, ſtaring at each other.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo! and is this the end of all the cloſetings?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: What the devil!—it muſt be all a dream.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Wife!!—Lady Dinah my Wife!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! dear George, forgive me, but I muſt laugh, or I can't exiſt—ha, ha, ha! oh, my Couſin Dinah!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Pray, Bella, ſpare your mirth, and tell me what I am to do—for I am incapable of thinking.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Do! why run to Lady Dinah—fling yourſelf at her ſeet, tell her you had no idea of the bliſs that was deſigned you—and that you'll make her the tendereſt, fondeſt Huſband in the world—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh, Couſin, for once forget your ſprightlineſs—I cannot bear it—Seymour, what am I to do?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: My dear George, I pity you from my ſoul—but I know not what advice to give you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, then ſeriouſly I think—ha, ha, ha! but 'tis impoſſible to be ſerious—I am aſtoniſh'd you are not more ſtruck with your Father's tender cares for you.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Have you no mercy, Bella?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You have none upon yourſelf, or inſtead of ſtanding here with that countenance ſi triſte, you wou'd be with Mr. Drummond.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: He is, indeed, my only reſource—I'll fly to him this inſtant, and if it fails me—I am the moſt miſerable man on earth.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: What can induce Mr. Hargrave to ſacrifice ſuch a fellow as George, to a Lady Dinah?—Prepoſterous!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Her rank and fortune—and I dread the lengths to which his obſtinacy may carry him; he has no more reſpect for the divinity of Love, than for that of the Aegyptian Apis—Let us find Harriet, and tell her the ſtrange ſtory; ſhe is not the only perſon, I fear, to whom it will be painful.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Is it poſſible that Lady Dinah, in the depth of her wiſdom, can imagine ſuch an union proper?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Be merciful—Love has forc'd Heroes to forget their valour, and Philoſophers their ſyſtems—no wonder he ſhou'd make a Woman forget her wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Egad, ▪tis a ſervice of danger.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Danger! ſure you've no qualms?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: No, no, child—no qualms—the reſolution with which I could go thro' an affair of this ſort, would in another hemiſphere make my fortune—but hang it, in theſe cold northern regions there's no room for a man of genius to ſtrike a bold ſtroke—the foſtering plains of Aſia, ſor ſuch talents as mine!

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Now I think England's a very pretty ſoil.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why, aye, if one could be ſure of keeping clear of a dozen ill-bred fellows, who decide on the conduct of a man of ſpirit at the Old Bailey, then indeed we need not care; for an air of Ton, and a carriage, on whatever ſprings it moves, introduces one to the beſt circles—But let us conſider our bottom—this girl was plac'd under the care of the old gentlewoman, by a perſon of credit.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Pho, pho, what! ſhe brought a recommendation—don't we know how eaſily a character is to be had—ſpotleſs as ſilver, or as bright as gold! 'tis a wonder ſhe did not afford a name too; I warrant ſhe had ſufficient reaſons to conceal her own.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: It does look like it, and there's a myſtery in the affair—Now, myſteries, as my Lady ſays, we have a right to explain as we pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Aye, to be ſure—and this is the explanation. She is an unprotected, artful girl, who having caught a taſte for the life of a fine Lady, thinks the ſhorteſt way to gratify her longing, is by gaining the heart of ſome credulous fool, who'll make her his wife for the ſake of her—Beauty.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: True—That with this view ſhe told her ſtory to Mr. Drummond, who—innocent ſoul—not ſeeing her drift, introduced her here, where ſhe attempts to ſucceed, by playing off her artillery on the gunpowder conſtitution of George Hargrave, Eſq; the younger.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Oh, delightful!—why, if I continue with my Lady, I ſhall be her miſtreſs as long as ſhe lives—and now I think on't, I believe that muſt be our plan—You and I can be married juſt the ſame, you know.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Oh, juſt the ſame, my dear, juſt the ſame; nothing ſhall prevent that— [aſide] but my being able to coax you out of the Two Hundred.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Hark! here comes the Juſtice—ſlip away, and leave me to manage him—I know I can make him uſeful—You need not be jealous now.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Jealous! no, no; I have liv'd among the great too long, to be tormented with ſo vulgar a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Hah, hah! have I caught you, my little Pickſey? Come, no ſtruggling—I will have a kiſs, by Jingo.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Lud! you are the ſtrangeſt Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: You are wondrous coy, methinks.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Coy—ſo I ſhould—What have Gentlewomen without fortune, to recommend 'em elſe?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Aye—but that roſy, pouting mouth tells different tales, I warrant, to the fine Gentlemen in London. I have been thinking you'd make a pretty little Houſekeeper—yes you would, Huſſey—yes you would—will you come and live with me?

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p:
Oh, dear Sir—I ſhould like it vaſtly; but I think you had better go to London with me—I aſſure you, my
Lady ſpeaks very highly of your talents in the law—and ſhe has great intereſt—ſo, as ſoon as ſhe is Lady Dinah Hargrave—Your Worſhip is acquainted with that affair, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes; my friend has told me of it—but under ſtrict injunctions of ſecrecy.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Secrecy! aye, to be ſure—but I dare ſay Mr. Drummond has been informed of it.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Oh, I know nothing of him—he's queer and cloſe; one can never get him in at a bout—he's not ſtaunch.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: I believe he is not ſtaunch to our match; and if that is prevented, we ſhall leave the country directly.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Why, what can prevent it, Sweety?

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Perhaps Mr. Drummond's advice; for he can manage Mr. Hargrave.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Ah—but my advice will go as far as his, I believe; and do you think I'll part with you—you little wicked rogue you?

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Then if you find the match is likely to go off, you muſt uſe all your intereſt to bring it to bear; and then we ſha'n't part, you little wicked rogue you.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: That I will—I'll plead for the wedding as vigorouſly, as if I had an hundred guineas with a brief.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Well—but d'ye mind me? I don't like the ſtranger this ſame 'Squire uſher'd here.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Not like her! why, ſhe's a deviliſh fine girl;—adad, the warm ſparkling of her eyes catches one's heart, as if it was made of tinder.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Upon my word—a deviliſh fine Girl—the ſparkling of her eyes!—

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Oh—I don't mean—that is—Oh, I would rather have one kind look of thine, ſweet Mrs. Sukey—for t'other I dare not ſquint at.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Hah!—I believe you are a Coquet—but however, I have certain reaſons to wiſh this beautiful Angel out of the houſe. I have obſerved looks that I don't like, between her and young Hargrave—and—you comprehend me—whatever interrupts the marriage, we are gone.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: I underſtand you—you may depend upon me—let me ſee—how ſhall we manage to get her out of Drummond's clutches?

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: That's your buſineſs—I ſay, that muſt be done, and you muſt do it.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: To be ſure, Mrs. Suſan—let me conſider—

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: We muſt have no qualms, Mr. Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: We will have none—but what your ſmiles, ſweet Sukey, can diſperſe—I muſt venture a little—the tender paſſions make one do any thing. Omnia vincit amor, ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: She ſhall be ſent packing.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Have I not given you the word of a Magiſtrate?—But come now, give me one kiſs, you little dear, cruel, ſoft, ſweet, charming, baggage.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Oh, fye—you won't aſk for wages, before you've done your work.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Stop—don't run ſo faſt—don't run ſo faſt, Huſſy—

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I wiſh I had known it before matters had been carried ſo far—on a ſubject of this nature no woman can be affronted with impunity.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I▪ am careleſs of her reſentment—I will never be her huſband—nor huſband to any woman, but her to whom I have given my vows.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Hah!—have you carried your affair ſo forward?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have made that enchanting Girl the offer of my heart and hand, and tho' her delicacy forbids her, while our families remain unknown to each other, to give the aſſent my heart aſpires to—yet ſhe allows me to • atch hopes, that I would not forfeit to become maſter of the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: There's a little of the ardor of youth in this—the ardor of youth, George—however, I will not blame you▪ for twenty years ago, I might have been tempted to enter the liſts with you, myſelf.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I ſhou'd fear leſs to meet a Hector in the field—in ſuch a cauſe the fury of Achilles would inſpire me—and I would bear off my lovely prize from amidſt the embattled phalanx.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Bravo—I like to ſee a man romantic in his love, and in his friendſhips—the virtues of him who is not an enthuſiaſt in thoſe noble paſſions, will never have ſtrength to riſe into fortitude, patriotiſm, and philanthropy—but here comes your Father, leave us.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: May the ſubject inſpire you with reſiſtleſs cloquence!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: So, Mr. Hargrave.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: So, Mr. Drummond—what, I gueſs your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you do, and I hope you are prepared to hear me with temper.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: You'll talk to no purpoſe, for I am fixed, and therefore the temper will ſignify nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Strange infatuation! why muſt George be ſacrificed to your ambition?—ſurely, it may be gratified without tying him to your Lady Dinah.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: By marrying her yourſelf—which, till now, I ſuppoſed to have been your deſign—and that wou'd have been ſufficiently prepoſterous.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What!—make me a ſecond time the ſlave of hyſterics, longings, and vapours!—no, no, I've got my neck out of the nooſe—catch it there again if you can—what, her Ladyſhip is not youthful enough for George, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: True—but a more forcible objection is the diſproportion in their minds—it wou'd not be leſs reaſonable to expect a new element to be produced between earth and fire, than that felicity ſhou'd be the reſult of ſuch a marriage.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Pſha, pſha—what, do you ſuppoſe the whole world has the ſame idle notions about love and conſtancy, and ſtuff, that you have? D'ye think, if George was to become a widower at five and twenty, he'd whine all his life for the loſs of his deary?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Not if his deary, as you call her, ſhould be a Lady Dinah; and if you marry him with no other view than to procure him a happy widowhood, I admire the election you have made—but, if ſhe ſhou'd be like my loſt love—my ſainted Harriet—my—oh! Hargrave—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Come, come, I am very ſorry I have moved you ſo—I did not mean to affect you—come, give me your hand—'ſbud, if a man has any thing to do with one of you fellows with your fine feelings, he muſt be as cautious as if he was carrying a candle in a gunpowder barrel.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: 'Tis over, my friend—but when I can hear my Harriet named, without giving my heart a fond regret for what I have loſt—reproach me—for then, I ſhall deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Well, well—it ſhall be your own way—but come, let me convince you that you are wrong in this buſineſs

—'sbud! I tell you it has been the ſtudy of my life to make George a great man—I brought Lady Dinah here with no
other deſign—and now, when I thought the matter was brought to bear—when Lady Dinah had conſented—and my Son, as I ſuppoſed, eager for the wedding—why!—'tis all a flam!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: My good friend—the motives, from which you wou'd ſacrifice your Son's happineſs, appear to me ſo weak.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Weak!—why, I tell you, I have provided a wife for George, who will make him, perhaps, one of the firſt men in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: That is, ſhe would make him a Court Dangler, an attendant on Miniſters levees—one whoſe ambition is to be foſtered with the cameleon food of ſmiles and nods, and who would receive a familiar ſqueeze with as much rapture as the plaudits of a nation—oh—ſhame—to transform an independent Engliſh Gentleman into ſuch a being!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Well, to cut the argument ſhort—the bargain is ſtruck, and George ſhall marry Lady Dinah, or never have an acre of my land, that's all.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: And he ſhall never poſſeſs a rood of mine, if he does.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: There, I thought twou'd come to this: what a ſhame it is for a man to be ſo obſtinate!—but hold—faith, if ſo, I may loſe more than I get by the bargain—he'll ſtick to his word.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: I am very much ſurprized, Mr. Drummond—Sir—that I can't be left alone in the diſcharge of my magiſterial duties, but muſt be continually thwarted by you.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: This interruption, Mr. Juſtice, is ill-timed, and rather out of rule—I cou'd wiſh you had choſen another opportunity.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: No opportunity like the preſent—no time like the preſent, Sir—you've cauſe, indeed, to be diſpleas'd with my not obſerving rules, when you are continually breaking the laws.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! let us hear—what hen-rooſt robbery have you to lay to my charge now?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, you may think to turn it off with a joke, if you pleaſe—but for all that, I can prove you to be a bad member of ſociety, for you counteract the wiſe deſigns of our legiſlators, and obſtruct the operations of juſtice—yes, Sir, you do.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Don't be ſo warm—what is this affair?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p:
Why, the poacher, whom we committed laſt night,
Mr. Drummond has releaſed, and given money to his family—How can we expect a due obſervance of our laws, when raſcals find encouragement for breaking them?—Shall Lords and Commons in their wiſdom aſſemble in Parment, to make laws about hares and partridges, only to be laughed at? Oh, 'tis abominable!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Very true; and let me tell you, Mr. Drummond, it is very extraordinary that you will be continually—

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Peace, ye men of juſtice—I have all the regard to the laws of my country, which it is the duty and intereſt of every member of ſociety to poſſeſs—If the man had been a poacher, he ſhou'd not have been protected by me—the poor fellow found the hare in his garden, which ſhe had conſiderably injured.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Ho, ho—what, the raſcal juſtifies himſelf! an unqualified man gives reaſons for deſtroying a hare!—Zounds, if a gang of ruffians ſhou'd burn my houſe, wou'd you expect me to hear their reaſons?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Ah, there it works—Suſan's my own [aſide.]—there can be no reaſons—if he had found her in his houſe, in his bed-chamber—in his bed, and offer'd to touch her—I'd proſecute him for poaching.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Oh, bluſh to avow ſuch principles!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Look'ee, Mr. Drummond, though you govern George with your whimſical notions, you ſha'n't me.—I foreſee how it will be as ſoon as I'm gone—my fences will be cut down—my meadows turned into common—my corn-fields laid open—my woods at the mercy of every man who carries an axe—and, oh—this is noble, this is great!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Indeed, 'tis ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I'll take care that my property ſha'n't fall a ſacrifice to ſuch whimſies—I'll tye it up, I warrant me—and ſo, Juſtice, come along.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: We were talking on a ſubject, Mr. Hargrave, of more importance, at preſent, than this; and, I beg you'll hear me farther.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p:
Enough has been ſaid already, Mr. Drummond,—or if not, I'll give you one anſwer for all—I ſhall never think myſelf obliged to ſtudy the humour of a man, who thinks in ſuch oppoſition to me; I have a humour of my own, which I am determined to gratify, in ſeeing George a great man—He ſhall marry Lady Dinah in two days; and all the fine reaſoning in the world, you will ſee, has
leſs ſtrength than my reſolution—'Sbud, if I can't have the willing obedience of a Son, I'll enjoy the prerogatives of a Father—Come along, Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: D'ye hear with what a fine firm tone he ſpeaks?—This was only a political ſtroke, to reſtore the balance of power.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Why don't you follow, Sir? [Exit Juſtice.] My ſon ſhall be a great Man!—To ſuch a vanity as this, how many have been ſacrificed!—He ſhall be great—The happineſs of love, the felicities that flow from a ſuitable union, his heart ſhall be a ſtranger to—but he ſhall convey my name, deck'd with titles, to poſterity, though, to purchaſe theſe diſtinctions, he lives a wretch—This is the ſilent language of the heart, which we hold up to ourſelves as the voice of Reaſon and Prudence.
Miſs Morley!—Why this penſive air?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I am a little diſtreſs'd, Sir—the delicacy of the motive which induced you to place me here, I am perfectly ſenſible of—yet—

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Yet—what, my dear Child?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Do not think me capricious, if I intreat you to take me back to your own houſe, till my uncle arrives—I cannot think of remaining here.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Then 'tis as I hoped [aſide]—What can have diſguſted you?—Come, be frank; conſider me as a friend, to whom you may ſafely open your heart.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Your goodneſs, Sir, is exceſſive—Shall I confeſs—the Lady who will ſoon have moſt right here, treats me unkindly.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: That you can't wonder at—Be aſſured, I will effectually defend you from her inſults—But do you not pity poor George, for the fate his father deſigns him?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Yes—I do pity him.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: If I dared, I would go ſtill further—I would hope, that, as his happineſs depends on you—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Let me not alarm you—I am acquainted with his paſſion, and wiſh to know that 'tis not diſpleaſing to you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: So circumſtanced, Sir—what can I ſay?—He is deſtined to be the huſband of another.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: It is enough—I bind myſelf to you from this moment, and promiſe to effect your happineſs, if within the compaſs of my abilities or fortune. But, that I may know my taſk—favour me with the key to your Uncle's character.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: My Uncle poſſeſſes a heart, Sir, that would do him honour, if he would be guided by it—but unhappily he has conceived an opinion that his temper is too flexible—that he is too eaſily perſuaded—and the conſequence is—he'll never be perſuaded at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I am ſorry to hear that—a man who is obſtinate from ſuch a miſtake, muſt be in the moſt incurable ſtage of the diſorder. However, we'll attack this man of might—his flexibility ſhall be beſieged, and if it won't capitulate, we'll undermine it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! my Uncle is in a ſtate of mind ill prepared for yielding—He returned from Spain with eager pleaſure to his native country; but the diſguſt he has conceiv'd for the alteration of manners during his abſence, has given him an impatience that you will hardly be able to combat.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Take courage—let me now lead you back to your young companions—I am obliged to be abſent a ſhort time—but I'll watch over you, and, if poſſible, lead you to happineſs.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Where the devil does my clerk ſtay with Burn! But I know I'm right—yes, yes, 'tis a clear caſe. By the ſtatute Anno Primo Caroli Secundum—obtaining goods on falſe pretences, felony, with benefit—hum—with benefit.—Now obtaining entrance into houſes, upon falſe pretences, muſt be worſe—I have no doubt but it amounts to a burglary, and that I ſhall be authorized to commit—Ho! here they are! where is my clerk and Burn?

div.stage: Enter Mr. HARGRAVE and Lady DINAH.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Aye, aye, here's a pretty buſineſs—bringing this Girl into my houſe now is the conſequence of Mr. Drummond's fine ſeelings—he will never take my advice—but I'll ſhew him who is beſt qualified to ſiſt into an affair of this ſort—and yet I am a little puzzled—a ſtroller—

sp.speaker: Lady. D.
sp.p: It is, doubtleſs, a ſtrange ſtory, Mr. Hargrave—and I beg that you will yourſelf queſtion my ſervant concerning it.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why, what can ſhe mean—what can her deſign be?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: To you I ſhou'd imagine her deſign muſt be very obvious, 'though Mr. Drummond's penetration was ſo eaſily eluded—By aſſuming the airs and manners of a perſon of rank, ſhe doubtleſs expects to impoſe on the credulity of ſome young heir, and to procure—a jaunt to Scotland—that, Mr. Hargrave, I take to be her deſign.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Hoh, ho, is it ſo—now I underſtand your Ladyſhip—if your man can prove what he aſſerts, be aſſured, Madam, ſhe ſhall not ſtay in my houſe another moment—I'll young heir the baggage.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: But conſider, dear Mr. Hargrave, before you take any ſteps in this affair—that 'tis poſſible, we may have been deceived, for tho' my ſervant avows having been on the moſt intimate terms with her, he may be miſtaken in her perſon, you know.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I ſhall inquire into that—ſhe ſhall pick up no young heirs here, I warrant her—I ſhall ſee into that immediately.

div.stage: Enter Juſtice, leading in JARVIS by the button.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Here's the young man—the witneſs—I have brought him up in order to his examination.—Here,—do you ſtand there.—In the firſt place,— [ſettling his wig] in the firſt place, how old are you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Fiddle de de—What ſignifies how old he is?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Why, yes it does—for—if he is not of age—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pſha, pſha—I'll examine him myſelf. How long is it ſince you left the ſtrollers you were engaged with?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: It is about two years ſince I had the honour of being taken into my Lady's ſervice,—and at that time I left the company.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And did you leave the young woman in the company at that time?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I did, Sir, and I have never ſeen her ſince till now.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am ſtrangely puzzled—I don't know what to think—

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: It is indeed a difficult caſe—a very difficult caſe—I remember Burn in the chapter on Vagrants—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Prithee, be ſilent—at this time you are not likely to clear up matters at all.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: A Juſtice be ſilent!—a ſilent Juſtice!—a pretty thing indeed—are we not the very mouth of the law?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What does your Ladyſhip adviſe?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I adviſe!—I don't adviſe, Mr. Hargrave.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Why then, let the parties be confronted—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Aye—let the parties be confronted.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let us be confronted: if I once ſpeak to her, ſhe'll be too much daſh'd to be able to deny the charge.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Did your honour call?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Go and tell my daughter, that I deſire ſhe'll bring her viſitant here—the young Lady.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Two glaſſes of brandy, and tremble yet!—I wiſh I had ſwallow'd the third bumper.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Hargrave, it will be exceedingly improper, that I ſhould be preſent at this interview, ſo I ſhall retire till the affair is ſettled.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: 'Sbud, my Lady, if you go, I'll go too—and the Juſtice may ſettle it as well as he can.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Nay, if you are for that—I ſhall be gone in a crack—I won't be left in the lurch—not I.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Bleſs me! I am ſurpriſed—only conſider what an imputation may be thrown on my character.
So—now 'tis determin'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Robert inform'd us, Sir, that you requeſted our attendance.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Yes, Harriet—I did ſend Robert—'tis about an odd affair—I had rather—but I don't know—pray, Madam— [to Emily] be ſo kind to tell us if you know any thing of that perſon—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: No, Sir, I believe not—I do not recollect—I may have ſeen him before.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Oh, Miſs Jenny—you don't recollect—what, you have forgot your old companion William Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I do not remember indeed, that I was ever honour'd with ſuch a companion—and the miſtake you have made of my name, convinces me that I never was.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Pſha, pſha—this won't do now—you was always a good actreſs, but behind the ſcenes, you know, we uſed to come down from our ſtilts, and talk in our own proper perſons—Why ſure, you will not pretend to forget our adventures at Colcheſter—the affair of the Blue Domino at Warwick—nor the plot which you and Mrs. Varniſh laid againſt the Manager at Beconsfield.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear Sir, nothing is ſo evident, as that the man has miſtaken this Lady for another perſon—I—hope you'll permit us to go without hearing any more of his impertinence.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: If he is miſtaken, no excuſes will be ſufficient—I don't know what to ſay—'tis a perplexing buſineſs—but I wiſh you wou'd be ſo kind to anſwer the man, Madam.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment has kept me ſilent till now, Sir—and I muſt ſtill be ſilent—for I have not yet been taught to make defences.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Dear Madam—why ſurely you have not forgot how often you have been my Juliet, and I your Alexander.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir,—if you dare utter another word to that Lady, I'll break every bone in your body—leave the room, raſcal, this inſtant.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: You are too hot, George—he ſhall ſtay—and ſince things have gone ſo far, I'll ſift the ſtory to the bottom—If the young Gentlewoman is not what he repreſents her, ſhe has nothing to fear—Speak boldly—where did you laſt ſee that Lady?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Aye, ſpeak boldly—give her a few more circumſtances, perhaps ſome of them may hit—People on occaſions of this ſort have generally ſhort memories.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you cannot allow theſe horrid—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I do allow, Sir—and if you can't be ſilent, leave the room.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, or elſe you'll be committed for contempt of Court. Now, for your name, child, your name, and that of your family.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: The name of my family, demanded on ſuch an occaſion, I think myſelf bound to conceal—my ſilence on that ſubject, hitherto aroſe from a point of delicacy—that motive is now greatly ſtrengthened, and I refuſe to diſcover a name—which my imprudent conduct has diſgraced.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Ho, ho—pray let the Lady be treated with reſpect—a perſon of Conſequence—ſtands upon Conſtitutional ground—a Patriot, I'll aſſure you—ſhe refuſes to anſwer Interrogatories.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot be any longer a ſilent witneſs of theſe inſults—Your preſence, Madam, ſupports that raſcal, or he ſhou'd feel the immediate effect of my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Your reſentment will be unneceſſary Sir, if he is not ſupported by truth—I ſhall take care that he is properly puniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: A Gentleman in a coach-and-ſix enquires for your honour—his name is Morley.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Hah—'tis my Uncle—I no longer dread his preſence—now, Sir, you will be ſatisfied concerning my family.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Her Uncle—Heavens! Madam, what have we done!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Done!—nothing—madneſs!

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: So, ſo—the niece of a man who keeps a coach and ſix!—we are got into a wrong box here—
ſhe can be no Patriot, our Patriots don't ride in coaches and ſix.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Stay, Sir—we have not done with you yet—you muſt now exhibit another part in this ſcene—what ſays your oracle Burn to ſuch a fellow as this, Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: Ay, you raſcal—'tis now your turn—thou art a vilifier, a cheat, an impoſtor—'tis a downright conſpiracy—The niece of a man who keeps a coach and ſix!—why, how doſt think to eſcape? thou'lt cut a noble figure in the pillory, Mr. "Alexander the Great."

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Sir,—your honours—I humbly crave pardon for my miſtake—I cou'd have ſworn the Lady had been my old acquaintance, the likeneſs is ſo ſtrong.—But I humbly aſk pardon—my Lady!—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Expect no protection from me, I diſcharge you from my ſervice from this moment.—The dilemma into which you have deceived me excites my warmeſt reſentment.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Since Your Ladyſhip gives him up, he has no other protection—Who's there? [Enter Servants] Secure this fellow till I have leiſure to inquire into the bottom of the affair—he is only the Agent, I am convinced.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, but I am dumb—or we ſhall loſe the reward.] I beſeech your honour—'twas all a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Take him away.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Hah—are you ſuſpicious, Sir!—I hope Suſan has not put me in this fellow's power—I muſt be ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.p: 'Tis a conſpiracy, that's certain—and will, I believe, come under Scan. Mag.
for 'tis a moſt ſcandalous Libel—but hold—'gad-ſo—let me ſee—it can be no libel; 'tis a falſe ſtory—if it had been true—aye, then indeed—if it had been true
—but I'll go home and conſult Burn, and you ſhall know what he ſays. Egad, it won't be amiſs to get out of this Morley's way.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Surely ſhe muſt have been privy to this ſcandalous plot—but 'tis no matter—my fate is at its criſis.—Mr. Morley's arrival fixes it.—At this moment my fortitude forſakes me, and I tremble to meet the Man, on whoſe caprice depends, the value of my exiſtence.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: MORLEY.
sp.p: A Pretty freak indeed!—a pretty freak, in return for the care and ſolicitude with which I have watch'd over you—I have broke with the Doctor for his ſhare in this romantic affair.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I am much concerned, Sir, that compaſſion to my ſituation ſhould have led that worthy Man to take any ſtep that you can think unpardonable—but when he found he cou'd not move my reſolution, he thought it his duty to accommodate me with a retreat amongſt perſons of reputation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Retreat!—ſo, whilſt I was condemning my ſweet inno • ent Niece for ſtubbornneſs, wilfulneſs, and ingratitude—ſhe was only gone to a retreat to ſit under elms, liſten to the cawing of rooks, and carve her melancholy ſtory on the young bark—Oh, Emily, Emily! you ought to be made repent of this retreat, as you call it, as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I do repent.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What's that?—repent!—my dear Emily, I am rejoiced to hear you ſay ſo—I knew you was always a good Girl on the, whole—come, it ſha'n't be a misfortune to you—I'll make Baldwin ſwear, before the ceremony, that he'll never reproach—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt not deceive you—my repentance does not concern Mr. Baldwin—he is—pardon me, Sir—my ſentiments with regard to him, are, if poſſible, ſtrengthen'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Are they ſo, Miſtreſs? then farewell to humourings—ſince your ſentiments are ſo ſtrong, your reſolution cannot be weak—'twill enable you to bear this dreaded fate with heroiſm.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I am glad you can be ſo ſportive with my unhappineſs, Sir—where you jeſt with miſery, you always deſign to leſſon it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Aye, that won't do—the eaſineſs of my temper. Girl, has been my great misfortune. I never made a miſtake in trade in my life, never, but have been perſuaded, and liſten'd to advice, till I have been half ruined
—but I'll be reſolute now for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Surely, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Aye, aye—I underſtand that ſpeaking face—there is not a line in it, but calls me Monſter—however, Madam, after your retreat, you can never expect to be the wife of another—ſo ſnap Baldwin while you can.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, allow me to live ſingle, I have no wiſh for the married ſtate—ſince he to whom my heart is devoted muſt be the huſband of another.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No wiſh for the married ſtate! ha, ha, ha!—why, 'tis the ultimate wiſh of every woman's heart—you all want Huſbands, from your doll to your ſpectacles.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: The perſon with whom one enters into ſo important an union ſhou'd be at leaſt agreeable, or—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What an age this is!—Why, huſſey, in the days of your great Grand-mother, a Girl on the point of marriage had never dared to look above her lover's beard—and would have been a wife a week before ſhe cou'd have told the colour of her huſband's eyes—But, now, a Girl of eighteen will ſtare her ſuitor confidently in the face, and, after five minutes converſation, give an account of every feature and peculiarity, from his brow to his buckle
—But pray, Madam, what is itin Baldwin now, that ſo particularly hits your fancy?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: His perſon is ungraceful, his manner aſſuming, and his mind effeminate.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Very true—and is not this the deſcription of all the young men of the age?—but he has five thouſand a year, that's not quite ſo common a circumſtance. Come, take the pencil again, lay on coarſer colours, or you won't convince me the picture's a bad one—conſidering the times.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Hah!—how different is Mr. Hargrave!—if I could urge his merit [aſide]—You have heard my objections ſo often, Sir, that the repetition can have no weight—but, ſurely, I may urge my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By all means, it ſhall be conſider'd, therefore—John, order my carriage up, we are going directly—tho' you don't deſerve it—the very moment we reach Groſvenor-ſtreet, you ſhall be tied faſt to Baldwin, who is now waiting there with the parſon at his elbow—and we'll this moment ſtep into the carriage, and away as briſkly, as if Cupid was our coachman—come now, don't put on that melancholy air—'tis only to turn the tables—fancy that I hate Baldwin—that you are driving to Scotland, and I purſuing you—why the horſes will move ſo ſlowly, you'll be ready to ſwear they don't gallop above three rood an hour.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I entreat you, dear Sir, ſtay, at leaſt, till to-morrow.—Oh, where is Mr. Drummond?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not a moment.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You have not yet ſeen Mr. Drummond, to whom I am ſo much oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have made enquiries, and have heard a very extraordinary character of Mr. Drummond; we can make him acknowledgments by letter—and you may ſend him gloves.—I know your deſign, you hope he will be able to talk me out of my reſolution—and, perhaps, I may be a little afraid of it myſelf,—and ſo, to avoid that danger, we'll go directly.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo late, Sir,—and the night is dark.— [Aſide] Yet why ſhould I wiſh to ſtay here?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No more trifling—conduct me to the family, that we may take leave. If you complain of this as an act of tyranny—be comforted, Child, 'tis the laſt you'll experience from me—my authority will expire with the night, and tomorrow morning, I ſhall be my dear Niece Baldwin's moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What, refuſe me your aſſiſtance in ſuch an hour—talk to me of prudence in a moment when I muſt be mad, if I am human! yes, be prudent, Sir, be prudent,—the man who can be diſcreet when his friend's happineſs is at ſtake, may gain the approbation of his own heart, but mine renounces him—Where can Mr. Drummond be?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: I am at your command in every thing—I aſk you only to reflect.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, I do reflect, that in a few hours ſhe will be irrecoverably another's—loſt to me for ever—unfeeling brute! to ſacrifice ſuch a Woman to a man whom ſhe deſpiſes!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: What then is your reſolution?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: There is but one way—ſhe hangs on the point of a precipice, from which, if I do not ſnatch her in an inſtant, nothing can retrieve her.—We will follow the carriage on horſeback; let your chaiſe attend us with our ſervants—I'll force her from this tyrant Uncle, carry her inſtantly to Dover, and in a few hours, breathe out my ſoul at her feet—in ſweet ſecurity in France.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Conſidering your plan is an impromptu, I admire its conſiſtency—but, my dear George, have you weighed all its conſequences?—your Father—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Will perhaps diſinherit me—be it ſo—I have ſix hundred a year independent of his will—and ſix hundred a year in France with Emily Morly—kingdoms! empires! paradiſe!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: But are you certain ſhe will partake it with you?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No—but ſuppoſing the worſt—I ſhall, at leaſt, have had the happineſs to preſerve her from a fate ſhe dreads—for the reſt I will truſt to time and my ardent paſſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Pity the days of chivalry are over, or what applauſe might'ſt thou not expect—advent'rous Knight!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Come, we have not a moment to loſe—let us get our people ready to follow, the inſtant the carriage ſets out.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: But, George—George—I'll not accompany you a ſtep, after the Lady's in your protection—for if your Father ſhou'd ſurmiſe that I have any hand in the enlevement, I can hope for no ſucceſs, when I aſk him for my charming Harriet.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Agreed—let me have your chaiſe, and leave me to my fortune—I will not endanger your happineſs—this key will let you in at the garden-door—you may give fifty reaſons for your ſhort abſence.—Now, Cupid, Venus, Jove and Juno, leap into your chariots, and deſcend to our aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: She's gone, and my alarms are at an end—'tis plain I had never the leaſt foundation for my fears—what paſs'd in the garden was mere gallantry, and the effects of her art; he ſuffered her Uncle to carry her off with an indifference that tranſports me. How weak have I been, to allow my credulity to be impoſed on by their ſuggeſtions, and my temper ruffled at a time when 'twas of ſo much importance to me to have been ſerene!

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady, ſhe's gone—the delightful obſtinacy of the old Uncle—It is well Mr. Drummond was not here—I was afraid—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Your joy wears a very familiar aſpect—I know ſhe's gone.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: I beg pardon, my Lady—I thought I might congratulate your Ladyſhip on her being carried off—I was terribly afraid—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Yes, you have had moſt extraordinary fears on the occaſion. You ought to have known, that the man whom I had receiv'd as my Lover, could never have felt any thing like a ſerious paſſion for ſuch a girl as that.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo! how ſoon our ſpirits are got up! [aſide.] I am ſure, my Lady, 'twas not I who occaſioned the interview in the garden to-day, that ſo enraged you, and confirmed your fears—you was ready enough then to believe all that was ſaid againſt her.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: How dare you reproach me with the errors which you led me into?—'twas your fears I was govern'd by, and not my own; and your ridiculous plot was as abſurd as your fears.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: As to the plot, my Lady, I am ſure 'twas a good one, and would have ſent her packing, if the Uncle hadn't come—'twasn't our fault he came—We have had the ſame trouble, and—ſervice is no inheritance, and I hope your Ladyſhip will conſider—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: How dare you think of a reward for ſuch conduct?—If you obtain my pardon, you ought to be highly gratified—leave me, Inſolent, this moment.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: Ha!—and dare you uſe me in this manner?—I am glad you have betrayed yourſelf in time, when I can take a ſevere revenge?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I have gone too far—Now muſt I court my ſervant, to forget the reſentment which her impertinence occaſioned—Well, 'tis but for a ſhort time—the marriage over, and I have done with her—

I muſt retire to my apartment, to recover my compoſure: perhaps he'll viſit me there—but not to talk of veneration and reſpect again—Oh! I'll torment him for that. Nothing gives a Woman ſo fine an opportunity of plaguing her Lover, as an affectation off jealouſy: if ſhe feels it, ſhe's his Slave; but, whilſt ſhe affects it—his Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How very unfortunate, that Mr. Drummond is abſent!—he would have oppoſed the reaſoning of Lady Dinah; and prevented their departure—Sure, never any thing was ſo cruel.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, there's no bearing it—Your Father is quite a manageable being, compared to this odd, provoking mortal, whoſe imagined flexibility baffles art, reaſon, and every thing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Never ſhall I forget the look, wild, yet compoſed—agonized tho' calm, which ſhe gave me, as her Uncle led her out. Her Lover muſt poſſeſs ſtrange ſentiments, to reſolve to marry her, in ſpite of her averſion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sentiments! my dear—why he's a modern fine Gentleman; there is nothing he's ſo much afraid of as a fond Wife—If I was Miſs Morley, I'd affect a moſt formidable fondneſs, and ten to one but ſhe'd get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I wonder where Sir Charles is—he paſs'd me in the hall, and ſaid in a haſty manner, he muſt tear himſelf front me for half an hour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
I wonder rather where your Brother is—but the heart of a woman in love, is as unnatural as the oſtrich's; it
is no longer alive to any ſentiment but one, and the tendereſt connexions are abſorbed in its paſſion.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I hope it is not in your own heart, you find this picture of love.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh—here's one of our truants, but where's the other?—poor George, I ſuppoſe, is binding his brow with willows.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: That's not George's ſtyle in love—he has too much ſpirit to croſs his arms, and talk to his ſhadow, when he may employ his hours to more advantage at the feet of a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Where is my Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: On the road to France.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: France!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Unleſs Mr. Morley has as much valour as obſtinacy—for George has purſued him, and, by this time, I dare ſwear has gained poſſeſſion of his Niece.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! how I doat on his Knight-errantry!—commend me to a lover, who, inſtead of patiently ſubmitting to the circumſtances that ſeparate him from the object of his paſſion,—boldly takes the reins of Fortune in his own hands, and governs the accidents which he can't avoid.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How can you praiſe ſuch a daring conduct? I tremble for the conſequences!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: What conſequences, Madam, can he dread, who ſnatches the woman he loves from the arms of the man ſhe hates?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Maſter, Sir, is returned—the Lady fainted in the chaiſe, and he has carried her to Mr. Drummond's.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: The devil!—is he at home?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, Sir—and Mr. Morley is come back too—he drove thro' the gates this minute.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay, then George will loſe her at laſt—he was a fool for not purſuing his route.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: He has no chance now, but thro' Mr. Drummond; and what can he hope? Mr. Drummond has only reaſon on his ſide, and the paſſions of three to combat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, here he comes—and Mr. Hargrave, as loud as his huntſman.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Let us fly to the parlour, and then we can ſend intelligence of what paſſes to George.

div.stage: Enter Mr. MORLEY and Mr. HARGRAVE.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis fact—matter of fact, upon my honour—Your Son was the perſon who took her out of the coach.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Sir, it is impoſſible!—ha, ha, ha!—my Son!—why, he's under engagements that wou'd make it madneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you may depend upon it, tho fit is on him now, for he clapt Emily into a chaiſe, whilſt an impudent puppy faſten'd on me—egad! twenty years ago I'd have given him ſauce to his Corniſh hug—I could not diſcern his face—but t'other I'll ſwear to.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: George! look for George there! I'll convince you, Sir, inſtantly—ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Where's George?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, my Brother is at Mr. Drummond's.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: There! I knew it could not be him, though you would not be perſuaded.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: What a plague! you can't perſuade me out of my ſenſes—Your Son, I aver, took her out of the coach—with her own conſent, no doubt, and on an honourable deſign, without doubt—Sir, I give you joy of your daughter.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: If it is on an honourable deſign, they may live on their honour, or ſtarve with it—not a ſingle ſous ſhall they have of me—but I won't yet believe my George cou'd be ſuch a fool.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Fool! Sir—The man who loves Emily gives no ſuch proof of folly neither—but ſhe ſhall be puniſhed for hers—'twas a concerted affair, I ſee it plainly, all agreed upon—but ſhe ſhall repent.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Your reſentment, Sir, is extraordinary—I muſt tell you that my Son's anceſtry, or the eſtate to which he is heir—if he has not forfeited by his diſobedience, are not objects for the contempt of any man.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Very likely, Sir,—but they are objects to which I ſhall never be reconciled—What! have I been toiling theſe thirty years in Spain, to make my Niece a match for any man in England—to have her fortune ſettled by an adventure in a poſt-chaiſe, an evening's frolick for a young ſpark, who had nothing to do but puſh the old fellow into a corner, and whiſk off with the girl? Sir, if there was not another man in the kingdom, your Son ſhou'd not have my conſent to marry Emily.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: And if there was not another woman in England, I'd ſuffer the name of Hargrave to be annihilated, rather than he ſhould be huſband to your Niece.

div.stage: [Hargrave and M • rl • y walk about the Stage diſordered.]

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Gone!—her Uncle arrived, and the amiable girl gone—What infatuation, Mr. Hargrave, cou'd render you ſo blind to the happineſs that awaited your family?—I'll follow this obdurate man—where's George?—look for George there—he ſhall hear reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: There, Sir—that's the perſon to whom you muſt addreſs your complaints.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Unfortunate!—I have made diſcoveries, that muſt have ſhaken even your prejudices— [to Mr. Hargrave]—but this Uncle!—ſurely, my dear Harriet, you might have prevailed.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, this gentleman is Mr. Morley—Mr. Drummond, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Hah! I beg pardon, Sir, I am rejoiced to ſee you; I underſtood you were gone.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: I was gone, Sir; but I was robb'd of my Niece on the road—ſhe was taken out of my coach, and carried off—which forced me to return.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Carried off!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, carried off by George, whom you have trained to ſuch a knowledge of his duty.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Stopt on the King's highway, Sir, by the fiery youth, and my Niece dragg'd from my ſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What's this right too?—By heaven, it is not to be borne.
