sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: At your houſe, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: What a country am I fallen into! can a perſon of your age and character approve of ſo raſh and daring—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Let George do what he will—he's ſure of his approbation.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Gentlemen—if you are ſure Miſs Morley is at my houſe, I am patience itſelf—ſhe is too rich a prize to be gained without ſome warfare.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Sir, I am reſolved to—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: So, Mr. Hargrave! ſo, Sir!—what, your Son—this new inſult deprives me of utterance—but your Son—what is the reaſon of this complicated outrage?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: My dear Lady Dinah, I am as much enraged as you can be—but he ſhall fulfill his engagements—depend on it, he ſhall.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Engagements!—what the young Gentleman was engaged too!—a very fine youth! upon my word.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Your honour is concern'd, Sir—and if I was ſure he was drawn in by the girl's art, and that he was convinced of the impropriety—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Drawn in by the girl's art!—whatever cauſe I may have to be offended with my Niece's conduct, Madam, no perſon ſhall ſpeak of her with contempt in my preſence—I preſume, this gentleman's ſon was engaged to your daughter, but that's not a ſufficient reaſon for—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Daughter! impertinent!—No, Sir, 'twas to me that he was engaged—and, but for the arts of your Niece—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: To you!—A matrimonial negociation between that young Fellow and you!—Nay then, 'fore George, I don't wonder at your ill temper—A diſappointment in love at your time of life muſt be the devil.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Mr. Hargrave, do you ſuffer me to be thus inſulted?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why, my Lady, we muſt bear ſomething from this Gentleman—the miſtake we made about his Niece, was a very ugly buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I entreat you, Madam, to retire from a Family, to whom, if you ſuffer me to explain myſelf—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What new inſolence is this?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I would ſpare you, my Lady, but you will not ſpare yourſelf—Bluſh then, whilſt I accuſe you of entering into a baſe league with your Servants, to blaſt the reputation of an amiable young Lady, and drive her from the protection of Mr. Hargrave's family.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What! a league with her Servants?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And how dare you accuſe me of this—Am I to anſwer for the conduct of my ſervants?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: The villainy of your ſervants is the conſequence of thoſe principles with which you have poiſon'd their minds. Robb'd of their religion, they were left without ſupport—againſt temptations to which you, Madam, have felt, Philoſophy oppoſes its ſhield in vain.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I feel his ſuperiority to my inmoſt ſoul—but he ſhall not ſee his triumph [aſide]—Is it your virtue which prompts you to load me with injuries, to induce Mr. Hargrave to break through every tie of honour—through the moſt ſacred engagements!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I have juſt heard theſe terms, nearly as much proſtituted by your ſervants, who reproach you with not keeping your engagements to them.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ha! Am I then betrayed?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Miſs Morley, Sir, commanded me to lead her to you—I cannot aſk you to pardon a raſhneſs, of which I do not repent.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Then I ſhall make you, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Hah—did you really wiſh to return to me?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I left Mr. Drummond's, Sir, the moment I knew you were here.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: That's a good girl—I'll remember it. Come, child, the coach is at the door, and we muſt make ſpeed to retrieve our loſt time. But have a care, young Gentleman,—tho' I have pardon'd your extravagance once, a ſecond attempt ſhall find me prepared for your reception.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: If Miſs Morley conſents to go with you, Sir, you have no ſecond attempt to fear. But ſince this moment is the criſis of our fate, thus I entreat you [kneeling]—you, to whom I have ſworn eternal love, to become my wife. Conſent, my charming Emily, and every moment of my future life ſhall thank you.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What, without my leave?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: At ſuch a moment as this, meanly to diſguiſe my ſentiments would be unworthy of the woman, to whom you offer ſuch a ſacrifice—obtain the conſent of thoſe who have a right to diſpoſe of us, and I'll give you my hand at the altar.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: That you will not, my frank Madam—ſo no more ceremony, but away.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: And will you go, impenetrable man—I have diſcovered, Sir, that your Niece is the daughter of Major Morley, who was one of the earlieſt friends of my youth—He would not have borne the diſtreſs ſhe now endures—I will be a father to his orphan Emily, and enſure the felicity of two children, on the point of being ſacrificed to the ambition and avarice of thoſe, on whoſe hearts Nature has graven duties, which they wilfully miſpel.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What, Sir, are you not content with the inſults you have offer'd to me and Mr. Hargrave, but you muſt interfere with this Gentleman in the diſpoſal of his Niece!

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: What right have you, Sir, to diſpoſe of our Children?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Aye, very true, you don't know how to value the authority of a parent.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Miſtaken Men! into what an abyſs of miſery—perhaps of guilt, wou'd you plunge them!—they claim from you happineſs; and you with-hold it—they ſhall receive it from me. I will ſettle the jointur'd land of my Harriet on Miſs Morley, and George ſhall now partake that fortune to which I have already made him heir.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Ay, there's no ſtopping him—what can theſe ſervants have told him, that makes him ſo warm?—Egad, I'll hear their tale.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Why, Sir, this is extraordinary friendſhip indeed! fettle jointur'd lands—I am glad Brother Tom had prudence enough to form ſuch a connection, 'twas ſeldom he minded the main chance—Honour and a greaſy knapſack, running about after ragged colours, inſtead—

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Sir, I have ſerved, and I love the profeſſion.—The army is not more the ſchool of honour than of philoſophy—A true ſoldier is a citizen of the world; he conſiders every man of honour as his brother, and the urbanity of his heart gains his Country ſubjects, whilſt his ſword only vanquiſhes her foes.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Nay, if you have all this Romance, I don't wonder at your propoſal—however, tho' your jointure lands might have been neceſſary for Major Morly's Daughter—My Niece, Sir, if ſhe marries with my conſent, ſhall be obliged to no man for a fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: The inſolence of making me witneſs to this is inſupportable—Is this you, Sir, who this very morning paid your vows to me?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Pardon, Madam, the error of this morning; I imagined myſelf paying my devoirs to a Lady who was to become my Mother.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Your Mother! Sir—Your Mother!—Mr. Hargrave—ha, where is Mr. Hargrave?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I am here, my Lady—and have juſt heard a tale of ſo atrocious a nature from your ſervants—that I wou'd not, for half my eſtate, ſuch an affair ſhou'd have happen'd in my family.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And can you believe the malicious tale?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Indeed I do.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Mr. Drummond's arts have then ſucceeded.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Your arts have not ſucceeded, my Lady, and you have no chance for a huſband now, I believe, unleſs you prevail on George to run off with you.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p:
Inſolent wretches!—order my chaiſe, I will not ſtay another moment beneath this roof—when perſons of my
rank, thus condeſcend to mix with Plebeians—like the Phoenix, which ſometimes appears within the ken of common birds, they are ſtared at, jeered and hooted, till they are forced to aſcend again to their proper region, to eſcape the flouts of—ignorance and envy.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Well ſaid, a rare ſpirit, faith, I ſee Ladies of quality have their privileges too.—

div.stage: [As Lady D. goes off, Geo. fixes his eye on his Father, and points after her.]

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: My dear Boy, I believe we were wrong here—and I am heartily glad we have eſcaped—but I ſuppoſe you'll forget it when I tell you I have no objection to your endeavouring to prevail on this gentleman—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nothing, dear Sir, can prevent my feeling the moſt unbounded gratitude for the permiſſion—now may I hope, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Hope, Sir!—Upon my word I don't know what to ſay, you have ſomehow contriyed to carry matters to ſuch a length—that aſking my conſent is become a matter of form.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I begin to find out, that in ſome caſes one's children ſhould lead.—Come, Sir,—do keep me in countenance, that I mayn't think I yielded too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Your conſent, Sir, is all we want, to become a very joyous circle—let us prevail on you to permit your beloved Emily to receive the addreſſes of my Godſon, and you will many happy years hence recollect his boldneſs on the road, as the moſt fortunate reneounter of your life: you ſhall come and live amongſt us, and we'll reconcile you to your native country: notwithſtanding our ideas of the degeneracy of the times, we ſhall find room enough to act virtuouſly, and to enjoy in England, more ſecurely than in any other country in the world,—the rewards of virtue.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Sir, I like you—promiſe me your friendſhip—and you ſhall diſpoſe of my Niece.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I accept the condition with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: There it is now, this is always the way—perſuaded out of every reſolution—a perfect proverb for flexibility.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, permit me—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Nay, no extacies—Emily diſlikes you now you've got me on your ſide. What ſay you? [to Em.] don't you begin to feel your uſual reluctance?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: The proof I have given of my ſentiments, Sir, admits of no diſguiſe—or, if diſguiſe were neceſſary, I could not aſſume it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Enchanting frankneſs! my heart, my life muſt thank you for this goodneſs. But what ſhall I ſay to you— [to Drummond] to you, Sir, to whom I already owe more than—

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p:
To me you owe nothing—the heart, George, muſt have ſome attachments—Mine has for many years been
center'd in you—If I have ſtruggled for your happineſs—'twas to gratify myſelf.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! why will you continually give me ſuch feelings, and yet refuſe them utterance?—Seymour, behold the happieſt of men!

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: May your bliſs, my dear George, be as permanent as 'tis great.— [To Hargrave] Allow me, Sir, to ſeize this propitious moment to aſk your conſent to a ſecond union—Permit me to entreat Miſs Hargrave for her hand, and I'll prove George a vain boaſter, when he calls himſelf the happieſt of men.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why, Sir Charles, you have choſen a very lucky moment—but there's no moment in which I ſhould not have heard this requeſt with pleaſure. Why, Harriet—if we may believe your eyes, you are not very angry with Sir Charles for this requeſt.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: A requeſt, Sir, which gives you ſo much pleaſure ought not to give your Harriet pain.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lord! you look ſo inſulting with your happineſs, and ſeem to think I make ſuch an aukward figure amongſt you—but here [taking a letter from her pocket]—this informs me—that a certain perſon—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Of the name of—Belville—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Be quiet—is landed at Dover, and poſting here—with all the fancy confidence our engagements inſpire him with.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Say you ſo?—Then we'll have the three weddings celebrated on the ſame day.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh mercy!—I won't hear of it—Love, one might manage that perhaps—but honour, obey,—'tis ſtrange the Ladies had never intereſt enough to get this ungallant ſorm mended.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: The marriage vow, my dear Bella, was wiſely framed for common apprehenſions—Love teaches a train of duties that no vow can reach—that refined minds only can perceive—but which they pay with the moſt delighted attention. You are now entering on this ſtate—may You—and You [to Bella, ſignificantly] and You [to the audience] poſſeſs the bli • sful envied lot of—Married Lovers!
